reviewText:
☺ Easy to play.
☺ Local co-op.
☺ Suitable for most ages.

☹ Short.
☹ Difficulty spikes.

Pressure can be summed up rather easily, short and sweet. The gameplay is a cross between a racer and shoot em up where you control a steam powered buggy and have to contend with a variety of enemies as you try to make it to the finish line without running out of steam...literally, if you dordle or allow one too many enemies to escape you'll not have enough pressure to keep your buggy going and grind to a halt.

After a race you have the option to spend any coins collected to upgrade your buggy with a variety of weapons, tools, rams and a beefier buggy and while it doesn't really change how the game plays, the upgrades are very much required to progress and even on Normal Difficulty, you may hit some challenging spikes in difficulty. This isn't helped by seemingly being unable to redo won races during the campaign to collect more coins for upgrades - at one stage, I had to sell all previous unlocks in order to buy the parts needed to give me a fighting chance.

Levels are largely similar, hold accelerate and fire and hurtle towards the finish line, boosting when available. Of special note are the few 'boss' levels which I found very enjoyable and changed up the pace of things enough to keep the game engaging.

The presentation is lovely and the couple of cutscenes are humorous. It controlled well with an XBox Controller and was certainly playable, though slightly clunky with keyboard controls and the entire game can be played in local co-op and although Online Multiplayer is an option, at the time of playing there were no servers available.

Pressure is rather enjoyable but very short, crossing the finish line at around three hours to clear the campaign races. It's certainly hard to recommend this game at full price as a result of this, but what's on offer is well polished and fun - if you want a game to play with your kids and you happen to see this game on offer, I'd say give it a go!

reviewText:
Pressure is a racing combat arcade game. You play as Morgan, a young man in his steam-powered attack vehicle, racing across the land battling evil minions to get the lake's water back from Count Soap II, who stole all of it to force the inhabitants to use his spa facilities.

Pros: Nice game for all ages with colorful graphics and humoristic characters. You don't race against time, but instead against the loss of pressure you vehicle has, which is replenished from fighting off other wacky vehicles and passing check points. You have a multitude of upgrades you can purchase between races, whether car chassis, bumper, main weapon and secondary weapon. There's a long list of varied levels with little repetition, and an increasing variety of baddies to shoot, some straightforward and some requiring specific tactics.

Cons: There is no story development to speak of (not that the game needs any). The game's focus isn't on the racing itself, but on completing the levels while killing all baddies and picking coins, so once completed there is little incentive to go back just to beat your time. The campaign mode doesn't allow to play back other levels, so you can't use your progression to do better in a past level.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!

As far as arcade-style games go, this is a fun one to play. Levels are quick, so you can hop in for a few levels and leave, great for young gamers, casual gamers, or anyone looking for short play sessions. The game is exactly what it advertises to be, so if it looks interesting to you, knock yourself out!

reviewText:
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Pressure just skip to Results and read from there.

Chasing Carrots creates a fun shoot 'em up arcade style driving game that keeps you on your toes. With silly lines and a rediculous story Pressure is the type of game that really pushes you at every turn.

Story:
Pressure, despite its low Metascore and rather dull describing reviews it’s actually quite a riveting game. Not too long, but fun till the end. Pressure has a rather funny, but very simple story. Pressure is about a young man who lives by a lake awakening to all the water being stolen. Who is the culprit you may ask? Well none other than an evil Sauna genius who decided to charge all of the community to use the lakes water from his sauna. In order to retrieve this water back from the depths of the evil sauna you must race through rivers, cliffs, mountains, buildings, and railways in order to defeat the evil geniuses waves of monsters.

Gameplay:
The levels are not timed with an actual timer, but rather a pressure gauge. As time moves on, the more you are hit, or as you progress through the course you gain or lose pressure. If the gauge goes to zero your car conks out and you lose the match. On the other hand if your car gets too shot up it can take extensive damage and blow up. So in order to win the race you need to go fast, avoid the bullets, and kill all the enemies. The game allows you to boost unlimited times, with each car offering different boost lengths, shoot unlimited ammo with many different guns, and use power ups. This game is like a blood bath, minus the blood and adding water.

Results:
The game isn't very difficult; it just has some interesting concepts which until you figure out how to properly use the game it seems rather difficult. With constant boosting, unlimited ammo, and nuclear weapons Pressure is a shoot 'em up racing game. Pressure offers a small campaign with multiplayer experience and brilliant high pressure (hah) action that keeps you on your toes. Don't be fooled you won't be racing against opponents in this epic as you'll be too focused on destroying everyone and everything in your way. If you like games where you can sit down for a short session and not have to dedicate too much time this is the game for you.

Pros:
+Smooth, easy gameplay
+Smart difficulty curve
+Simple but pleasant graphics
+Friendly story with simple characters
+Fast shoot 'em up gameplay
+Loads of upgrades that allow you to customize and further boost your car.
+Funny little story that isn't in any way inappropriate.
+Lots of interesting baddies and boss fights to keep you interested.
+Unlimited boosts and ammo, so you don't feel like you have to hold back.

Cons
-Not a racing game
-Enemies seem to repeat themselves after you complete the first world
-Hints are not given randomly, but rather as you progress throughout the game
-You cannot go back and play an old level in the campaign to grind up your car (if you are having difficulties)

reviewText:
As soon as I finished my first level of the game, I already knew what my conclusion will be. It's like eating the food that looks nice, but has a really bad taste, so people end up giving it a few bites and throwing away. Here is why I think this game is not worth your time and money.

Yes, I must say it's fun to shoot the enemies, but the game is made that way so you can't see anything beyond your vehicle. You just don't have time to look at your HP or Pressure which is located in the worst place possible. I have also found the main story quite rediculous as well as the rumor. I have played the game on several occasions with each session no longer than 10 minutes.

Let's see what the navigation through the game is like. The mouse behaves like someone is constantly pushing it forward and making you misclick pretty much all the time. The main menu looks fine, but as soon as you progress to your garage menu everything changes, literally. The main menu is just a simple menu with the text inside the buttons. However, the garage menu goes full 3D and there is no text anymore, you may as well click everywhere to try and find the correct menu. It actually has only 2 useful buttons, so I can't see any reason why developers would make it so complex.

The graphics are interesting so is the art. I enjoyed seeing all the explosions and other stuff, everything looks belivable. Couln't see much effects on what thought. On the other hand, I have an average computer and this game gives it a lot of trouble. I am not sure why this game overheats my graphics card more than CoH2 for example, but that's how it is. What about the sound? I found music really annoying, but it's still bearable. The sound effects of explosions and the vehicles are fine. Although the characters make the sound like they are about to have an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ everytime they are hurt.

I would say that if you do have this game, then you will probably play it about once a month for no more than 30 minutes at maximum. This is not something you want to go back to in a long time.

To sum up this whole thing, I'd say that this game has some nice art and visuals, but the gameplay is on major down side. If not on sale (80-90% off) then I would not recommend buying it, it's likely that you will regret it in the first 10 minutes of your gameplay.

reviewText:
I played pressure on easy with my sister. She's not much of a gamer but we had a lot of fun with this game. There isn't much of a story but whats here is quirky and adds to the charmy style of this game.

On easy we failed. A lot. Not because the gameplay is challenging but because the pressure system is very unforgiving even on easy. Even with the many failures we could always beat a level by just replaying it and we never had to grind past levels for upgrades which I would assume is more prominant on higher difficulties. Also I should not that we didn't die from damage ever except for a few times near the end of the short game.

Overall I liked this game and I got it very cheap in a weekly sale. BUT there is one con here. The gameplay is super repetitive. Even with the different weapon types and abilities it still was very repetitive. It never got to the point of the repetition being tedious or annoying, just a con.

I would only recommend playing this with a friend because that's what makes this type of game enjoyable. I feel that playing by yourself will make the repetition more evident. So yeah, pick this up on a sale and play it with a friend it was a  lot of fun and there is a lot of potential difficulty here.

reviewText:
While I had seen somewhat mixed (edging towards positive) reviews on this game, this is the kind that got my attention by its playthrough videos and screenshots. Sure enough, I was not disappointed when I gave it a shot myself.

You can get my first impressions of this title in this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m6Pj8m9jle8
* Warning: Steam though it would be a good idea to break all stereoscopic videos. Head to YT to watch it, make sure you are using Flash, not HTML5.

First off, maybe I'll get lenient because the game works very well with Tridef Ignition in stereo-3D using the driver's 2D+depth feature (Power 3D). The game simply looks excellent with added depth perception and given its nature, it adds all that much more to the experience, even going as far as helping the game play a lot!

Some can give it criticism for not having enough varied shmup features while others can find the lack of actual racing elements  sort of a letdown, for its price (even more so when it lands on sale) it actually falls very well within my expecations and the 10$ range sort of opens up tolerance for elements that may lack, but do not bring down the gameplay itself in a notable way.

Don't be too surprised - this is in NO way a racing game - rather a different take on a shmup, this one being loaded with SPEEDING elements. You won't beat anything by passing rather you have to speed through the levels and defeat the enemies with your gun, not your driving. In fact you're encouraged to drive THROUGH enemies, not around them (which I find quite satisfying; the ram mechanics are funny).

My only valid criticism could be on that aspect. I see this game as a sort of buildup to what it would've actually liked to be. This is sort of the beginning of the genre and I hope they can build a sequel and attempt to experiment more with an ACTUAL racing / shmup balance. This concept would definitely benefit from more actual race-like elements and maybe a POV that gives you more of a forward view.

Needless to say, this game is definitely a lot of fun. When it comes to a Yes/No scenario - a much easier type of review to do than an actual SCOCRE - I have to give this one a GO"."

reviewText:
This is a game that your children would enjoy... provided they can learn the controls. I haven't gotten very far into it, but from what I've seen, you play a mad scientist inventor type who enjoys his life in a lakeside cabin. The game begins with an overly cartoony cutscene showing that the bad guys have drained the lake for their evil purposes. Being the only one who cares about the lake, your character rushes out to battle in a steam-powered buggy -- which is ironic due to the fact that all the water (the source of steam) has been stolen.

Story aside, this game has a lot of irritations. (I wouldn't call them flaws -- the game is certainly playable, but it has minor annoyances that make the game unattractive.) The artwork is quite nice, but the humor expressed through the animation is slapstick and childish. Again, this would make a great game for children.

A major irritation (at least with keyboard and mouse) is the akwardness of the controls. For one, hard turning is impossible without getting disoriented. Also, you can't shoot and drive in different directions. Your aim is locked forward, which means that you can either finish the level within the time limit or with max kills.
Secondly, you're constantly being pushed forward. If you stop for a collectible, the enemies pass you, you can't catch up to them, and you're stuck with no pressure (fuel) and no powerups to attain more pressure.
Third, every level is more or less the same. I understand that most games (especially level-based games like this) can't stray too far from the original concept without making the game incredibly difficult to play or incredibly difficult to program. However, it seems as though you just have to shove your way through (battering ram is the only useful upgrade) while holding w" the whole time for every single level.

reviewText:
I feel its a bit harsh to say I don't recommend this game. If there was was a 'Maybe' option I'd take that but with just a Yes/No its got to be 'No'.

This game is OK.
Its not great, its not bad... its just kinda meh.

The game itself is quite simple: there is a single track with a few places to fall off a few ramps, jumps that down't really do anything and lots of enemies to shoot. You have 'pressure' in your car's steam engine that you use up gradually as you race down the track and you get it back again by passing the checkpoints or by killing enemies.

Where this game falls down is in driving down the course... quite a serious issue for a driving game. Its hard to keep the car going in the direction you want which is emphasized by the boosting system you need to use to be able to make the end of the track. All of this is before you add in the enormous amount of ordnance being fired by both you and the enemies. With some of the weapons there is so much flying about the screen that its really hard to keep track of where your car is and seeing turns before you get to them is almost impossible... add in enemies to that mix and I often found myself thinking I was one of the enemies.... don't get me wrong, its fast paced and fun just like a good arcade game, but like an arcade game chances are you'll only want to play it for a short time before you move on to something else.


The most disappointing aspect of this game is the upgrade system. Items have short 'fun' descriptions which don't really give you any idea of how worthwhile they are going to be and there is no chance to see what they do before you have committed to buying them. You can sell items later but you lose 1/4 of their worth so each time you change your mind you make the rest of the game that much harder. If only you could sell items for the same price you bought them for you could chop and change as much as you wished to try all the different options and make the best car for each track but as it is I felt button-holed into using one particular set of equipment and maximising it. After finishing the single player campaign I think I'd used 4/10 main weapons and 3/10 secondaries.

Its definately a good start to a game, but more options, a greater variety of enemies and the ability to change your car at will would make this game so, so much better. I'd still get confused by the chaos on the screen but that's a forgivable flaw in an arcade style game and is probably part of the fun.
